question: What can I do in the Studio?
answer: The Studio supports a wide range of recording, editing, and digitization projects. Examples include: - Record - Lectures or instructional videos - Voice-over narration for videos or slideshows - Individual or group interviews - Podcasts - Edit - Multi-track audio mixing - Short films, documentaries, or narrative videos - Creative, informational, or instructional videos - Digitize - Convert analog audio (cassette tapes, reel-to-reel tapes, vinyl records) to digital formats - Convert analog video (VHS tapes, DVDs) to digital formats Patrons using the Studio for digitization must follow copyright laws. For details, please see our Copyright Guide. Please note that digitization equipment is often used by the Center for Digital Inquiry and Learning (CDIL)
column3: and their projects may take priority. A general Studio booking does not guarantee digitization equipment will be available. Please contact CDIL directly to confirm availability."

question: How can I access the Studio as a first-time user?
answer: A reservation is required to use the Studio. You can reserve the space up to two weeks in advance through our online system, LibCal
column3: available on the Studio homepage. Same-day reservations may be available but are not guaranteed.

question: If your plans change
answer: please cancel your reservation to free up the space for others.

question: After booking
answer: you will receive a confirmation email. At the time of your reservation
column3: bring your Vandal Card to the Library Circulation Desk to check out the Studio key. The key must be returned to the Circulation Desk by the end of your reserved session."

question: What audio software and equipment is available in the Studio?
answer: Audio Software Installed on the Studio iMac: - Logic Pro X - Professional Digital Audio Workspace with default sample libraries & plugins, and preset preferences to interact with the MIDI keyboard and MOTU audio interface. Best for recording and editing. - MainStage - Live Performance software in companion to Logic Pro. - GarageBand - Simple Digital Audio Workspace with less functions than Logic Pro, but approachable interface. - Adobe Audition - Professional audio file editing software. - Audacity - Simple audio file editing software. - REAPER - A versatile and powerful digital audio workstation. - FL Studio - Digital audio workstation featuring a graphical user interface with a pattern-based music sequencer. - Sibelius - Music composition and notation software with sophisticated features like AI-powered accelerators, advanced options for markup and layout, Cloud Publishing, and the ability to work across any device. Audio Recording Equipment Available in the Studio: - Two Shure SM58 microphones - MPK Mini MIDI keyboard - Focusrite audio interface with 1/4 input

question: Need help getting started? Instructions are available in the Studio
answer: or you can contact Library staff for assistance."

question: What video software and equipment is available in the Studio?
answer: We have the following video software installed on the iMac: - Adobe Premiere - Professional video editing. - Final Cut Pro - Professional video editing. - Camtasia - Video editing by creating tutorials and recording presentations via screencast. - iMovie - Basic video editing. - Motion - Motion graphics application for animating graphics, images, and video. - Compressor - Encoding software for transcoding and exporting Final Cut Pro projects with custom output settings. We also have equipment available to record video in the Studio, including a green screen, a black backdrop, and portable light.

question: When is the Studio open?
answer: The Studio hours are the same as the Library building hours. Note that the Studio and the Library will be closed during national holidays, and the hours are subject to change for special circumstances. Please visit the Library Hours page for the most accurate and current hours.

question: Do I have to pay to use the Studio?
answer: Using the Studio is free of charge for students, faculty, and staff at the University of Idaho. However, patrons are responsible for any damaged or lost equipment in the Studio and fines for late loanable equipment. Please refer to the fine rate and replacement cost section of the [Studio terms of use](https://www.lib.uidaho.edu/studio/termsofuse.html).

question: Can I play loud music in the Studio?
answer: No. The Studio is not a completely soundproof space. Please be mindful of your noise level while using the Library Studio. While the space supports creativity and collaboration, loud sounds—including conversations, music, and instruments—can disrupt others. Use headphones for audio monitoring and keep volume levels reasonable. Thank you for your cooperation!

question: I have other questions, comments, or feedback. Who do I contact?
answer: Please contact Hanwen Dong, the Instructional Technology Librarian, at <hanwendong@uidaho.edu>.
